Overview on what is launching

We are launching two Pages management features. These features are admin permissions and Page post scheduling. We are excited to open up more Pages features that allow you to more effectively manage your Facebook Page. These features give you more control over your Page.

  • Admin permissions allows you to designate different permission levels to other admins on your Page. There are five different permission levels: Manager, content creator, moderator, advertiser, and insights analysit. Note that at default, all admins will have the highest permission level of Manager. Please take the time to decide the permission levels for the admins on your Page. You can view and change permission levels under Edit Page > Manage Admins. You can find more information here: https://www.facebook.com/help/?page=394501407235259.
  • Page post scheduling allows you to schedule your Page posts up to 6 months in advance, and as frequently as every 15 minutes. This is a great way for you to plan out your Page posts and prepare them in advance. You can find more information here: https://www.facebook.com/help/?faq=389849807718635&in_context.

We believe that these features will help you better manage your presence on Facebook. Let us know if you have any other questions.

to sum it up: Facebook's Edgerank system was created to filter out a large percentage of the content you 'think' or 'hope' or 'assume' is getting into Fans' newsfeeds.  And the reason is simple: they want you to pay for that content to be seen. Only problem is ads in the right column are seen far less than organic content in a newsfeed.  Facebook has done nothing to improve the Page/content experience for brands. I
don't most facebookers check their feeds on mobile? my android doesn't show paid ads or any kind of coloumn so what's the point?

So in other words, we spend our time and money to build Pages on Facebook and the percentage of people on Facebook that sees posts is abysmal. Posts and ads are two very different things. So in order to get posts to be seen we have to spend money and run ads. Fation calls this 'not fair'. I call this bullshit.

I have over 52,800 fans and it is apparent most don't see the posts or the likes would be higher than 1,500. It seems if fans do not stay active on our pages, they don't receive the posts.  I tested this by never commenting on a page I like and their posts disappeared from my own home page. Very sad.

Stacey Newell: Yes, that is one of the risks they posted in their IPO documents... They more people going Facebook on mobile, the more fragile their income model will be as they have no way to display their ads on mobile apps yet...
Just another reason why FB is not free. Sure, you can post all you want for free, but you'll have to pay for anyone to actually see it.

When you can spend a billion $$$ to buy a picture sharing site (just like that) - you must be rolling in the green stuff... so why make it even harder for businesses to succeed using FB as a marketing tool? This is no bueno in my book... even though I've known about this Edgerank business for a while now. #NeverLikedIt
Just goes to show every website no matter how big has a life cycle. Could be fb is on their downward trend.

The reason that not all posts are seen is because the posts work their way down the newsfeed as new posts are added. If your fan doesn't happen to be online when you post, they may not see the post, unless they scroll down and look through all of the other posts. The way to make sure your fans see the posts is to create a sponsored story ad. You will greatly increase the odds of your fans seeing your posts because the ads are set in place.
The Edgerank algorithm means that for over 80% of your fans, the post never appears in their newsfeed. It's not being missed or drowned out... it's not getting on the feed in the first place!

Create an artificial "shortage" of a product, so you can profit by selling access to the product. This is typical behavior or a con man, not a long-term, successful company that is going IPO.

Same on you, Facebook, for being anti-user in the name of generating more and more profits. You think you are high and mighty and untouchable, but your core anti-user philosophy and lack of common sense will be your downfall. 

I hope Facebook investors are aware of this kind of absurdity, and pop that bubble as soon as they can...
Wow. Facebook just lost a huge amount of respect from me.
Cant believe they really posted this, think it must of been because only 16% of us will see it!

While I understand the issue Facebook has (after all...every business needs to make money).  My basic issue as a business page owner is this...my fans (likes) made a choice.  That choice was to follow my business and the information we send out.  Now Facebook comes and takes both the customers and my choice away with an algorithim.  This seems fundamentally to be a bad decision.   While the news feed can become very busy, there has to be a way to allow the customers (the fans and the business) to reach each other without an arbitrary mathmatical equation.   My thoughts are that Facebook will likely become much less relevant to many businesses that don't have a large budget for this.  When relevancy drops...memes become the norm.  Oh No!!  It's too late!

Why is it that people expect to conduct business to make money on a free platform, but get mad when that free platform tries to make money to cover their expenses? I think part of the problem is they let people mooch off the platform for too long and now they expect it. I totally understand that I need to PAY to get customers, and cannot expect Facebook to just keep sending them to me for free. We have been showing small business how to take advantage of these changes for quite some time now...so stop complaining. Tell me where else you can get free marketing pages that send you leads all day long?
So you just want businesses to pay to have their posts seen now? Now that isn't cool

Pages organically reach about 16% of their fans on average.* This is not unique to business Pages. The degree of reach between users and their Friends is similar as well. Fans may miss content from friends or business Pages if they are not logged onto the site during a period when your posts are active in Newsfeed. Additionally, with all the content that is being shared daily, Newsfeed uses an algorithm to rank content based upon the likely interest to a user to help deliver the most relevant content. (*Read More here: comScore's The Power of Like http://bit.ly/comscorelikes)

 

By posting engaging content, you can increase the reach of your posts. Engaging content includes posting videos/photos, asking questions, sharing helpful and exclusive information and more. Another way to make sure your fans see your stories is by sponsoring your posts. To sponsor your posts:

 

a) Visit https://facebook.com/ads/create

b) Choose to boosts your most recent Page post.

c) Select your desired targeting, run dates, and budget.

d) Post regularly on your Page and we’ll distribute your most recent post to your target audience.

 

 

Be sure to continually check the performance of your ad(s) through the Ads Manager and Ad Reports. Use this information to improve how you target your ads and the content you use to engage your audience.

All submissions are governed by our Terms (https://www.facebook.com/legal/terms).  By submitting your photo, you grant Facebook permission to use your photo for all purposes, including marketing and promotion.  You also confirm that you have all rights necessary to grant this permission, including from all subjects in the photo and the person who took the photo.

Customers of high-end hotels website Luxury Link travel all over the world. And then many go on Facebook to discuss their experiences with their friends. So no surprise that Luxury Link, which offers trips such as touring vineyards in South Africa and exploring New Delhi’s historic bazaars, decided to use Facebook to reach new customers.

 

 

 

The company started advertising with Facebook Ads in February 2011 to engage with people who love traveling, enjoy luxury, and appreciate the experience Luxury link offers. To expand its customer base, the company now uses Friends of Connections Targeting to target friends of people who have liked its Facebook page Luxury Link.

 

Alia Henson, Luxury Link’s Social Media Manager, says the company’s overall objective has been to drive engagement and increase brand visibility for the well-traveled luxury customer. To begin her campaign, Alia created a page to generate more awareness.

 

Once people connect to the page, they can get information about new featured destinations and getaways. She has continued to enhance the page by adding tabs where people can sign up for the Luxury Link newsletter as well as search for hotels.

 

To fuel engagement, Alia regularly posts questions as status updates on the page. Recently, Luxury Link hosted an hour-long live chat about Fiji during which customers were able to interact with the brand. “Did you enjoy the Live Chat on Fiji yesterday?” a follow-up posts asks. “We want to know what destinations are of interest to you!”

 

In addition to sprucing up the company’s page, Alia has also introduced the Like button on LuxuryLink.com for nearly every product description page showcasing hotels and resorts. This gives customers another way to connect to the Luxury Link page and receive updates in their News Feed.

 

With the Like implementation on its website and by running continuous Facebook Ads, the company has grown its fans by 85 percent. Alia now runs Facebook Ads for her page in addition to running them to her website.

 

She began by running a campaign featuring a contest—the user simply had to like the page and they would have the option to enter themselves to win a trip to Italy, Greece or Guatemala. She used strong calls to action—“Shake off winter with a spring getaway” and Likes and Interests targeting for people she thought would be interested in her offerings. For example, some of these words included “Chanel”, “Fendi official page”, “Prada” or “Starbucks”. She also decided to target users who are married, as she thought these people would be more interested in getaways.

 

Most recently, Alia has taken advantage of a new type of product on Facebook called Sponsored Stories, which increase the visibility of people’s authentic interactions with brands on Facebook by surfacing them on the right-hand column of Facebook. Sponsored Stories allow her to reach friends of people who are already connected to her page by tapping the power of word-of-mouth referrals.

 

“Leveraging Sponsored Stories has enabled us to grow our base of like-minded consumers, and increase sales,” says Alia. “We have leveraged several tools such as IngBoo, which helps increase our visibility in the News Feed, so we can maintain a constant presence in our community.”

 

Alia says her activities on Facebook have been paying off. Traffic to the site from Facebook has increased 100 percent and revenue has also increased as a result. As of mid-August 2011, the company’s page had reached nearly 28,000 fans. Engagement with those fans on Luxury Link’s page has increased 200 percent.

 

Ever since running ads on Facebook, Alia has been following the comments from new fans who discuss different travel destinations on the page. One woman asked “Do you have anything in NYC…?” and another user responded with a link to Luxury Link’s New York City listings. In effect, the Page has become a central place where people are able to share information and learn from each other.

 

Alia plans to continue advertising with Facebook, as she is launching the second phase of Luxury Link's marketing campaign. She plans on using “page post like” and “domain like” Sponsored Stories to increase visibility to destinations, properties, and Luxury Link as a whole.

 

She also plans to continue to grow engagement by using Facebook Ads to increase attendance to Luxury Link events such as its Live Travel Discussions with industry experts on its Facebook Page. “Our goal is to continue to grow revenue by offering relevant content to our community and continuing to be the leader in social media marketing for the luxury travel industry,” she says.
data.subject: Hotel Site Luxury Link Grows Customer Base, Revenues on Facebook

As a photography equipment company, Tamron USA, knows something about the importance of focus. With Facebook Ads, the business is able to reach its most likely potential customers by targeting people who have listed photography-related terms such as “cameras,” “Canon,” “Nikon,” “photographer” and “photography” as Likes and Interests in their Facebook profiles.

The company, which sells all-in-one zoom lenses, telephoto zoom lenses, high-speed zoom lenses and others, first started using Facebook Ads in 2009 to raise awareness of the company.

 

“I feel we are getting great targeted exposure for minimal investment that can be adjusted on the fly so easily,” says Stacie Errera, Chief Marketing Officer of Tamron USA. “There's no other platform we use to promote our brand and products that's easier than Facebook.”

 

Stacie says her main marketing objective on Facebook has been to let people who have an interest in photography learn about the various promotions that the company offers throughout the year, including seminar events, photo contests and rebates on Tamron products.

 

At first, Stacie started advertising her product by linking her ad to relevant Tamron pages on the Web, where customers would be able to get information about a specific promotion. While this approach allowed people to get information right away, Stacie decided to try linking her ads to the Tamron Lenses Facebook Page.

 

She reckoned it would be a way for fans to access all the relevant promotions through one advertising outlet. At the same time, it would help her keep new fans and once they were connected and engaged with the Page. Why? Any time Tamron published to the Page, they would receive updates in their News Feeds.

 

In June 2011, Stacie noticed that Tamron Lenses was only 1,300 fans away from the 10,000 mark. She thought that a campaign focused on advertising the Page would be a great way to reach that goal.

 

To generate engagement, Stacie started posting status updates on promotions and tips on how to take better photos, as she believed this was a key advantage offered to Facebook fans. People would be able to receive these updates as well as exclusive and timely articles.

 

For example, one of her recent statuses in June offered a $50 mail-in rebate on Tamron's 18-270 VC PZD all-in-one zoom available for Canon, Nikon and Sony DSLRs with smaller sensors. “Just in time for Father's Day!” the status read. “Visit your local Tamron retailer for details or our website at www.tamron-usa.com”. This update allowed Facebook fans to take advantage of this offer as soon as it was posted.

 

When Stacie created her ads, she used both strong calls to action--‘Interact with your fellow Tamron fans!’--and Likes and Interests that were relevant to people who would be interested in Tamron Lenses. For example, her ads were targeted to people 24 and older whose Likes and Interests that were associated with “cameras”, “Canon”, “Nikon”, “photographer” or “photography”.

 

Stacie says she was impressed with Facebook’s advertising system because she says her campaign reached over 1 million users, and the CPM (cost per impression) value was effective. “That’s an excellent branding opportunity for us since we were targeting people with an interest in photography, rather than too broad of a target,” Stacie says.

 

As of early July 2011, the company had surpassed its short-term goal of 10,000 fans.

 

Ever since running ads on Facebook, Stacie has been reading the comments from new fans who share how much they like their Tamron lenses on the Page. One husband of a fan who answered Tamron’s call for Father’s Day photos and tips posted a comment on the Tamron Lenses Page, saying how much he admired his wife’s talent and told everyone how Tamron made her day.

 

Stacie says she is thrilled by the amount of communication that is happening among members of the Page, as there are fans who enjoy critiquing Tamron’s posts and engage with other fans to discuss their own critique. “I believe these new fans arrived at our Page as a direct result of our latest campaign,” she says.

 

Stacie plans to continue advertising with Facebook, as it was a top referring site for May and June, to continue facilitating a strong community where people can share their experiences. “Having the ability of targeting within the Facebook community is really terrific, says Stacie. “I love that we can seek out potential fans by getting specific with demographic selections and key words.”
data.subject: Tamron Lenses Focuses on Facebook Ads to Increase Exposure

If you’re friends on Facebook with somebody who has a Facebook friend in Vietnam, can your entire family stay with that person for a night or two—for free? Frédéric Colas is about to find out.

Frédéric, Héloïse and Estelle Colas

The French advertising executive and his family are gearing up for a trip around the world “powered by the social graph,” as he describes it. The way he sees things, the more than 750 friends that Frédéric and his wife Estelle have on Facebook together have more than 80,000 friends. That, he reckons, gives his family a huge network of friends of friends around the globe whose doors they can potentially knock on.

 

“When people travel overseas, it is often about going somewhere totally new where you don’t know anyone,” says Frédéric, 43. “We’re taking a completely different approach. Our challenge is: Can we go around the world leveraging Facebook to stay with Facebook friends and friends of friends?”

 

“Around the World with 80,000” friends, as he’s dubbed the unique voyage detailed in this video, is meant to be the social media era’s twist on Around the World in Eighty Days. In the 1873 Jules Verne novel, English nobleman Phileas Fogg attempts to win a wager with members of his gentlemen’s club by circling the globe in 80 days.

 

The Colas are making a different bet of sorts, theirs being that Facebook friends will actually do things that real friends do, such as letting your entire family crash at their house. “If we only go to places where we have Facebook friends or friends of friends, will we find someone to let us stay in Patagonia?” he asks. “Will we find someone in Salt Lake City?”

 

The yearlong voyage is really more of a business trip than an extended vacation. Frédéric, Estelle, and their eight-year-old daughter Héloïse are using the journey as a way to raise enough money to fund the building of a school in Burkina Faso, aimed specifically at helping girls in a country where the female literacy rate is just 15 percent.

 

For every night they’re hosted by somebody, the Colas will donate $50 that would have gone toward a hotel room to the school. What’s more, each time someone likes their We Like The World Facebook Page that they created to raise awareness for the cause, they’ll donate another $1. All told, the Colas plan to contribute some $57,000 (€40,000) of their own money to the $143,000 (€100,000) project. For the remainder, they’re looking for people to donate to the cause using their We Like The World donation application.

 

“At the end of the day, this will help more girls get an education,” says Frédéric. “Many major non-governmental organizations have shown that of all the causes for developing countries, the ones that have the best return on investment involve educating girls. The children of women who have five years of primary education are 40 percent less likely to die before the age of five” Frédéric says.

 

As the co-founder of Fullsix, a leading digital market group in Europe with 1,000 employees worldwide, Frédéric says he’s long appreciated the power of Facebook to inspire people to take action. “It can allow you to achieve things that you couldn’t even imagine were possible if you were just by yourself,” he says.

 

Through the app on the We Like The World Page, donations to fund the school’s construction will go through the French charity The Child’s Voice, which is partnering with the Colas on the project. To make sure people feel connected to the cause, donors will be able to contribute money towards a physical piece of the school—a door, a window, a desk—rather than giving an open-ended donation.

 

Along the way, the Colas plan to post regularly to the We Like The World Page about their hosts, the people they meet, and their various adventures. Among the countries they’ll visit include Canada, the United States, Brazil, Argentina, Chile, New Zealand, Tahiti, Singapore, Vietnam, Cambodia, India and Turkey. “We think people will be interested in the story of how many fans we’re adding or how many nights we’re hosted,” says Frédéric.

 

The We Like The World Page will also link to an exclusive Social Travel Map. “It allows you to view our itinerary and current location in real time and, when connecting to Facebook, locate your own friends, and compare their locations with our itinerary,” says Frédéric. “We’re looking for fans of our Page to reach out to their friends who live in places we’ll be visiting and say ‘hey, can you help these guys out?’”

 

The Colas are departing on July 3, 2011 from Paris. While Estelle, an executive with BETC Euro RSCG, will be helping Héloïse with her schoolwork, Frédéric, who created Procter & Gamble’s Digital Marketing Department in Cincinnati in 1996, will have his own work to do.

 

As they travel, Frédéric plans to interview top marketing leaders from around the world about how they’re embracing the digital age. His interviews will be published every two weeks in Advertising Age and other marketing magazines worldwide, and will also be available on www.cmoworldtour.com. “It will be the key people in marketing, and how they live in the digital age, from a personal and business standpoint,” says Frédéric. “I don’t think it’s ever been done before."

 

The Colas plan to return to London a year later in June 2012 before setting off to Burkina Faso. They’re of course hoping the power of word of mouth on Facebook will help them build the school through donations. But they’re also hoping it will build an appreciation of the ability of social media to change the world.

 

"We hope people will follow the story of our family going around the world and the story of the school being built,” says Frédéric. “We also want people to understand that the power of the network on Facebook allows you to have an impact on real life so that they can be inspired as well."

 

In the end, they want We Like The World to become a movement that will help other projects like their world tour leverage social media to grow and strive. “It is about making ‘social’ social," Frédéric, "or leveraging social networks to boost social progress."

 

In the Jules Verne book, Phileas Fogg wins his wager, succeeding in circumnavigating the globe by steamer and rail in 80 days. The Colas are similarly confident that betting on the support of 80,000 Facebook friends will get their school in Africa built.
data.subject: Ad Exec and His Family to Travel around the World "Powered by the Social Graph"

When Amy Norman and fellow mom, Stella Ma, founded Little Passports in 2009, they wanted to give kids a taste for foreign travel, even if the tots weren’t ready for a long plane ride. Families who subscribe to the company’s services today receive monthly packages in the mail with letters, cultural references and other goodies representing overseas lands.

While Little Passports has had no trouble transforming its clever idea into a thriving business, Amy decided she wanted to take things to the next level. So in January 2010, she started to advertise with Facebook Ads to drive awareness of her company.

 

When she started marketing on Facebook, Amy’s primary objective was to drive traffic to the company’s website and then convert the traffic into purchases. At the same time, she decided to create a Facebook Page for Little Passports because she wanted to help build a community that would reinforce her brand and the value of her product.

 

Soon after creating the Page, Amy noticed people were interacting heavily with it. Parents were purchasing Little Passports products and their kids were quickly getting attached to Sam and Sofia, the two characters with whom kids can “travel” abroad. Little Passports even started to receive letters from kids addressed to Sam and Sofia.

 

To engage with the fans, Amy started posting fun and creative status updates to the Page’s Wall. One status revealed that Sam and Sofia love sharing recipes and that one of their favorites is the Mexican mole recipe they call “Chocolate Chicken.” “Do you have any recipes you’d like to share with your Little Passports community?” the post asked. “We’d love to hear them!”

 

When Amy created her ads, she used both strong calls to action—‘Come meet Sam & Sofia - sign up today!’—and discounts. For example, for anyone who was connected to her Page, she offered 10 percent off and included the discount code ‘FBFRIEND’.

 

Thanks to Facebook Targeting, she was also able to reach a specific set of people most likely to be customers. She noticed that 90 percent of the Page’s fans were females between the ages of 25 and 55. So ads were targeted to females in this age range and to people whose Likes and Interests were associated with the following words: “being mom”, “I love my kids”, “kids activities”, or “parenting”.

 

Amy says she soon found that Facebook’s targeted advertising was extremely effective. The demand for her product increased, she says, and sales picked up. She says her average CPC (cost per click) was below her internal targets.

 

Ever since running ads on Facebook, Amy has had greater insight into the experiences customers have had with her company. One mom shared on the Page that she was so inspired by Little Passports that her family decided to host a Chinese exchange student. Another mom posted that she uses the Little Passports map so that her daughter can track where her relatives are posted in the military around the world.

 

As of May 2011, Amy plans to keep advertising with Facebook to continue to drive greater awareness to her company. “Facebook is the only online advertising platform we are currently using,” Amy says. “It is more targeted, relies more on word-of-mouth to generate sales, and, of course, meets our CPC objectives.”
data.subject: Children's Travel Education Company Uses Facebook Ads to Journey to the Next Level

Created to be the equivalent of a spa in a can, vitamin drink Purple Stuff aims to make consumers feel happy and relaxed in just a matter of minutes. But with an increasing number of relaxation beverages on the market, Springs, Texas-based Funktional Beverages knew it couldn’t be too relaxed about its marketing plan. So in March 2010, the company turned to Facebook Ads to help raise awareness of its new drink. 

 

 

Chief Marketing Officer Tim Lucas started advertising on Facebook to create a forum where customers could establish an emotional connection with Purple Stuff. He did this by first creating a Facebook Page called 

Purple Stuff and advertising the Page by running Marketplace Ads.

 

Soon, he noticed the Page was fostering a lot of interactions with both existing and potential consumers. One customer posted on the Page that she had grown to like the beverage so much that she was drinking Purple Stuff every day. She also posted that she even wore a shirt to school with the company’s name on it once a week. This post alone generated over 100 Likes. Shortly thereafter, her friends wanted shirts too.

 

“We send out fans on quests to tell us what displays look like in stores, what flavors they carry, if they are out of stock, what the store clerk thinks about the product, and on and on,” says Tim. “They are our boots on the ground and they are honest, hard-working and innovative.”

 

The Purple Stuff Page has also become a place where consumers share ideas, photos and personal videos about their experiences with the brand. When Tim has run campaigns promoting Purple Stuff, he has created a variety of Facebook Ads for different promotions, giveaways and local events.

 

In one campaign, the company promoted a photo contest in Arizona that allowed consumers to win Purple Stuff products and cash prizes. It also held an event during which customers were able to get free Purple Stuff soda by visiting the company’s truck and uttering the phrase “Spike said I can have free Purple Stuff!” With these incentives in the ad text coupled with a bright purple image of the soda, Tim quickly attracted thousands of consumers in a matter of days. 

 

After testing several different ads, he has learned that his core target audience on Facebook is 13- to 35-year-olds, with 60 percent of them being female.

 

Purple Stuff started off being carried in only a few stores in its original location, Texas. By the first quarter of 2011, Purple Stuff was available in more than 5,000 stores.

 

As of mid April 2011, the company had gained more than 145,000 fans to its Page, giving the company a large base of brand loyalists with whom to engage and gather feedback. As importantly, its activities on Facebook are also leading to sales.

 

“We drive foot traffic to stores that carry Purple Stuff and the retailers are amazed that we can do it at will and within hours of posting that it is available at their store now,” says Tim.

 

Tim plans to continue to use Facebook Ads to promote his product and to expand the awareness and distribution of the brand among even more people and stores across the country. “Facebook is as important to our brand as our company website in terms of effectiveness and excitement” Tim says.
data.subject: Purple Stuff Boosts Awareness and Sales of Beverage with Facebook Ads

Adele Cooper, Director, Global Customer Marketing & Communications

We were very excited to participate in Advertising Week in New York (the week of September 27). Advertising Week is special here at Facebook because it offers us the opportunity to share key milestones and discuss what we will be focusing on in the future.

 

I wanted to share a couple of key highlights from the week. During her keynote, our COO Sheryl Sandberg underlined that the web is ultimately about people and that amazing things can happen when people connect with one another and the things they care about online.

 

Sheryl reinforced that brands are part of the connections that people form online. Facebook enables brands not just to talk at their customers but to listen and build authentic relationships.

 

The power that comes from friends telling friends about your brand on Facebook allows brands to do real word-of-mouth marketing at scale for the first time. To watch a video of Sheryl’s speech, you can click on the following link: http://www.facebook.com/video/video.php?v=760718736391

 

In addition, Mike Murphy, our VP of Global Sales, hosted an agency panel that was moderated by David Kirkpatrick, author of The Facebook Effect. Our partners at Tribal DDB, Arc Worldwide and Wunderman discussed the power of marketing that connects with people by combining traditional and social media to engage people in meaningful ways. Click on the following link to watch the video: http://www.facebook.com/video/video.php?v=760705827261

 

If you were unable to attend, please visit our facebook.com/marketing Page for additional highlights including:

  • Nielsen’s announcement of an online GRP measurement
  • VP of Advertising and Global Operations David Fischer’s panel with our partners at P&G, Chase and Adidas

Adele Cooper

Director, Global Customer Marketing & Communications

Why is Warehouse 31’s Jack-o’-lantern smiling? Because in 2009, Chester Lee of social media company Creative Links ran Facebook Ads for a haunted house in St. Augustine, Florida called Warehouse 31. Using Facebook targeting that enabled the company to direct its ads to likely visitors based on their location and ‘Likes and Interests’, Warehouse 31’s Facebook Page  (http://www.facebook.com/Warehouse31) attracted more than 2,200 fans. As a result, many of these people ended up visiting Warehouse 31.

 

This year, Chester is using friend of connection targeting -- a targeting filter that allows advertisers to target friends of people who are connected to their Page, Group, or Event -- to attract people to the Warehouse 31 Page. 

 

Warehouse 31 is said to be Florida’s largest indoor haunted house. Filled with intense decorations and graphic scenes, the property and its contents are all designed to spook big time.

 

Things at this fright house got started in September 2009 when Red Mountain Entertainment, an event promotions company, teamed up with Chester to promote Warehouse 31. As a first step, Chester created a Page  for the haunted house. He then decided to promote the Page with Facebook Ads and used location and age targeting (users between 13 and 24).

 

In addition, he used ‘Likes and Interests’ targeting with keywords related to Halloween. Eventually, the Page generated more than 2,200 connections. Soon after, Chester created an additional tab on the house’s Page, featuring a coupon that people could use for admission into Warehouse 31.

 

Thanks to Creative Links’ successful campaign in 2009, the company decided to advertise its Page again this year. However, it decided to use the friends of connection targeting filter. What's more, it provided a  “Buy One Get One Free” offer in its ad text to anyone who connected to its Page.

 

As of mid October, more than 5,000 people had connected to the Page . Chester is hoping more people will be able to enjoy Warehouse 31 this year. “Facebook Ads are scary good!” he says.
data.subject: Facebook Ads Prove to Be ‘Scary Good’ for a Haunted House

Facebook announces the Blue Ribbon Award. The Blue Ribbon Award honors the top most creative and innovative and best performing campaigns and most engaging Pages each month. The clients and agencies will be recognized for their demonstrated abilities to engage with users in an authentic way. Their innovation exemplifies how best to approach advertising in the social web. Award winners receive a nice award plaque.

Lionsgate “Crank 2”

Lionsgate drove engagement, distribution and awareness of the Crank 2 movie by leveraging Facebook fan and event ad units to drive viewers into theatres.
Frito Lay Canada and OMD Digital Canada
Frito Lay Canada and OMD Digital Canada http://www.facebook.com/DoritosCanada Frito Lay Canada &OMD Digital Canada – Doritos Guru Campaign Doritos turned the brand over to Canadian consumers. They reached young snackers and enlisted their help to name the flavour of a new product and create a television ad. Canadian’s voted for the winner whose name was displayed on the bag (Scream Cheese). Their ad aired on TV and online, and they walked away with a guaranteed C$25,000 plus 1 % of net sales for the life of the product!
Warner Bros. Pictures, Inc. & MediaCom Interaction “17 Again”
Warner Bros. Pictures is being recognized for their execution of an innovative way to generate awareness and engage their audience for the movie release of 17 Again, leveraging the celebrity status of Zac Efron. With the Facebook Home Page Road Block, over 350,000+ customized Virtual Gifts, Zac Efron buttons, were given and received, generating over 30 million organic impressions on opening day. This is a solid example of the power of social distribution on Facebook.
Victoria’s Secret
Victoria’s Secret wanted to drive tune-in of the Victoria’s Secret Fashion Show on CBS. They received an overwhelmingly 116,332 RSVPs directly through their ad unit and received an overall engagement rate of 1.5%.
Cadbury Crème Egg and PHD
The Cadburys Creme Egg campaign was the first UK advertiser to take advantage of Facebook Virtual Gift reach block reaching over 8 million unique users in 24 hours. Users were able to send a virtual Creme Egg to their friends along with a personal message. This was also supported by a number of Video Engagement ads in the lead up to Easter and just after, to continue the user engagement.
Adidas and Carat LA
The adidas Orginals’ US campaign celebrated 60 Years of Originality, adidas-Style. The adidas House Party campaign was aimed at leveraging their relationships with top athletes and celebrities like David Beckhan, Missy Elliot and Katy Perry to create engaging video ads that encourage users to comment and become fans of their popular community page on facebook. The adidas Originals Facebook Page encouraged two-way conversations with adidas consumers and inspired them through compelling brand stories integrating relevant artists, musicians and celebrities. The David Beckham Video Ad was highly engaging and a favorite among fans.
Sony Pictures Classics “Every Little Step”
For Sony Pictures Classics, their goal was to get as many people to show up for screenings of Every Little Step using Events on the Page and Become a Fan ads. They built up a fan base for each movie and then utilized the status update tool and Updates to notify people of screenings in their city.
Twentieth Century Fox Home Entertainment LLC "Marley and Me"
Twentieth Century Fox Home Entertainment LLC increased awareness around the release of the Marley & Me DVD by promoting the brand through an iconic virtual gift.
The Walt Disney Corporation “Hannah Montana”
Hannah Montana The Movie is the first feature length movie starring Miley Cyrus as Hannah Montana. To ensure females 13-17 were aware of the movie’s release, Disney ran RSVP units to raise awareness about the release date. The event was a great success with over 125,000 Yes RSVP’s and over 34,000 Maybe RSVP’s. It had an opening weekend of $34 million, surpassing expectations to lead the biggest Easter weekend ever at the domestic box office.

H&M is being recognized for its innovative and engaging Facebook Page, a community of well over 1,000,000 Fans. With a focus on keeping the Page current and generating maximum viral distribution, H&M utilizes Page Tabs, constantly updating the Page around specific promotions, seasonal trends, store openings, and new designer launches. H&M takes advantage of all of the newest Engagement Ads, including Become a Fan, Polling, and Event RSVPs, targeted at national and local markets, to open demographics as well as fashion enthusiasts. Today, Facebook announced the forthcoming availability of usernames for user profiles and Facebook Pages beginning at 12:01am Saturday, June 13, 2009. Now you can have a personalized URL for your Page (facebook.com/yourname).

Read the Facebook blog to learn all the details: http://blog.facebook.com/blog.php?post=90316352130

Below is an FAQ specifically for Page administrators on the new process and how to obtain a username for your Page.

How can I secure a Username for my Page?
If you are an administrator of a Facebook Page, you will be able to choose your username just like a user selecting a username for their profile. There will be an interface available beginning at 12:01am EST on Saturday, June 13 for you to choose usernames for the Pages you administer.

I tried to secure a name for my Page but Facebook said the Page was not eligible. What are the requirements?
Your Facebook Page must meet two requirements: it must be live on Facebook prior to the May 31, 2009 cut-off date and have a minimum 1,000 fans as of May 31, 2009.

I am an administrator for multiple Pages on Facebook, how can I secure a Username for each of them?
If you are an administrator of a Page, you will be able to choose a username for each Page at http://www.facebook.com beginning at 12:01am EST on Saturday, June 13. There will be an interface for you to choose usernames for the Facebook Pages you administer.

Why should I register a username for my Facebook Page?
Usernames allow public entities to easily promote your presence on Facebook with a short URL (http://www.facebook.com/yourname). This username can be used in your marketing communications, company website and business cards.

What are the guidelines around creating a username for Facebook Pages?
Usernames were created to make it easier for Facebook users to identify their profile and share with others. As a public figure, business or brand with a Page on Facebook, your username should be straightforward and easy to remember. Facebook encourages you to consider the following when creating a username for Pages:
• Create a username that is as close as possible to your public figure or business name (e.g. AshtonKutcher, PizzaHut).
• If you own the rights to a given name, make it your username so that others cannot obtain it.
• Usernames can only contain alphanumeric characters (A-Z, 0-9) or a period (".").
• Choose a username you will be happy with for the long term. Usernames are not transferable.
• Your username must adhere to Facebook’s Statement of Rights and Responsibilities.

I accidentally selected the wrong/misspelled username for my Facebook Page. Can I revise it?
No. Once you have claimed a username by clicking the “Set Username” button, it is not possible to edit it, or to transfer your username to a different account on Facebook. Additionally, when an account is removed from the site, its username will not be made available to other users for security reasons.

Can I have more than one username for a Facebook Page?
No. Only one username is allowed per Page.

What should I do if someone’s username infringes my rights?
If you wish to report that someone’s username infringes your rights, please fill out our automated IP infringement form. The form is located at http://www.facebook.com/copyright.php?noncopyright_notice=1

I am an authorized representative for a public figure, brand or business and/or hold the rights to a trademark name. My username was claimed by another user. What can I do?
If you wish to report that someone’s username infringes your rights, please fill out our automated IP infringement form: http://www.facebook.com/copyright.php?noncopyright_notice=1

I would like to prevent individuals from registering a username that is associated with a trademark that I own.
To prevent the registration of a username that infringes your trademark, please go here: http://www.facebook.com/help/contact.php?show_form=username_rights

What is the process to request removal of an unauthorized Page of a public figure, brand or business?
If you wish to report that someone’s username infringes your rights, all you need to do is fill out our automated IP infringement form: http://www.facebook.com/copyright.php?noncopyright_notice=1

Will usernames such as “flowers” or “pizza” ever be available for Facebook Pages? Can I sign up on a waiting list?
At this time, generic words are not available as usernames. Facebook encourages all users and Page administrators to create a username that closely matches the true identity of their name or business.

For additional questions, visit the usernames Help page at http://www.facebook.com/help/?page=896

There’s a little extra dazzle in the Magic Kingdom today. Over the weekend, more than 100 million people had connected to the Walt Disney Company’s Facebook Pages, marking a major milestone for the brand. To highlight the achievement, Disney has released a video that chronicles the storied entertainment company’s activities on Facebook. 

 

 

Disney started fully managing its Facebook Pages back in August of 2009, with about 400,000 connections or likes, including on the Pages of Disney Pixar, Princess and the Frog, Toy Story, and Walt Disney Animation Studios. Since then, Disney’s presence on Facebook has grown to more than 200 managed Pages. Recently, the company has seen its fan base rise at a rate of 5 million fans a week.

 

Disney has received considerable social lift through purchasing Facebook Ads. But much of the growth around its legacy Pages and brand Pages has also been organic, as many people simply want to be connected to the brand on Facebook and they tell their friends about it.

 

The company hit its 100-million fan target late Saturday, a day before what would have been Walt Disney’s 109th birthday.

Here is a guest post from Elisa Haidt, Senior Marketing Manager at Adobe Systems and a member of the world-wide education marketing team.

Challenge: For this project, the challenge was clear: Increase awareness among college students for the launch of Adobe Student Editions in North America; we wanted students to know that they can purchase Adobe products at a steep discount for students (up to 80% off the full retail price).

Action: Facebook is a natural fit to help Adobe reach college students. But, we also know that students are bombarded with media each day. We needed to engage with students in a way that would be fun, show them what they could do with our products, as well as let them know about the discount.

To do this, we launched “Real or Fake”, a game embedded on our Facebook page that challenged users to determine whether a photo was real or “fake” (edited with Photoshop). The game was produced by Traction. It is no longer live on the Adobe Page on Facebook but for a live demo please click here.

The game lasted for 4 weeks, with 5 photos being posted each week. If a photo had been edited with Photoshop, a tutorial showed how that was done. And, at the end of the game, users were presented with information about Adobe Student Editions and there were 3 primary call-to-actions: 1) “Buy Now”, 2) “Play Again” and 3) “Share” the game with others.

Results: This game launched in November 2008 and ran for one month. Social ads on Facebook ran during the first two weeks. About 10% of our page visitors played the game and, of those who played, 6% clicked the "Share" button at the end of the game, and 6% clicked "Buy Now" at the end of the game. Due to this game and media placement, our page received over 6,000 new fans too.

Lessons Learned:

Engage, engage, engage (and deliver): By engaging with students with Real or Fake, we were able to draw attention to the launch of Adobe Student Editions, let students know about low pricing for them and we also showed them what they can do with our products.

Content and sharing: The game was appealing because of its fun content, and easy-to-play game. We knew students were engaged when a discussion board started with people posting what photos they were guessing correctly or incorrectly.

Integrate with media: Facebook’s targeted, engaging, and social ads let us get the word out; the success of this game was tied to having an integrated media strategy at the same time as launching the game.

In addition to you promoting your Page, you can also gain new fans for your Page by 1) engaging your existing fans, and 2) not losing fans.

Passive sharing from your fan to their friends

When you publish content such as links, photos, videos, and notes that your fans like or comment on, their interaction with your content will show-up on their own profile wall. When you fan's friends visit his/her profile, they will see your fan's interaction. If they also like it, they might become a fan too. These interactions may also show-up in their friends’ highlights section on the homepage. If your fans write on your wall, it will show-up in their friends' News Feed!

Active sharing from your fan to their friends

If your content is really compelling, your fans may use the Share feature and share your content directly with their friends.

Both the passive and active distribution can be powerful to enable your fans to help you spread your message. Note: when fans like or comment on a text update, there is no viral distribution; only when there is content attached such as links, photos, videos, and notes.

Interactions show up on the fan's profile wall - seen when a friend visits.


Interactions may also show up to fan's friends
Don't lose fans due to too much of a good thing...

The other way to increase fan count is to not lost fans. If you publish content is not relevant to your fans or publish too much, they may choose to “hide” you from their homepage or even un-fan your Page. What and how much is the right amount? Another easy way to promote pages to get more fans is for the news feed to show your friends when you join a page. FB used to do this for pages and groups, but no longer does. Removing that service broke a critical link in the viral marketting chain. All the other methods recommended in this post seem like compensation for that one missing link. Please consider reinstating that function.

FB advertising works great, but my experience is that when the change was made to remove join notices in the newsfeed, that the paid advertising was much less effective. On my page, I was paying for ~10 clicks/day. Those 10 clicks resulted in 1-3 additional fans/day. In the days before the change, those new fans resulted in referrals, so I avereaged 10-15 fans/day. Now it's just the 1-3, and not worth the cost.

"Just try not to spam them too often…" This comment in refererence to the "Suggest to Friend" approach was probably meant to be tongue-in-cheek, however, Spam is spam, and once is too often. And why would I do that to my own friends anyway? I've contacted the friends in my network who would care about my page. Sending unsolicited messages advancing a product to the others who wouldn't care is a great way to alienate friends.

A Page is a “voice” and is suited for publishing content to fans. All brands should have a Page.

- It is a super easy to publish content directly to your fans’ homepage with just one click by using the Publisher ("Write something..." box), and for fans to interact with you right from their homepage (e.g., comment, like, and share).

- No technical requirement to setup a Page. Why spend resources on website functionality and maintaining servers when it’s already available for free on a Page. Your resources are probably better spent developing great content.

Facebook Share and Connect allows your website visitors to easily share your content with their friends on Facebook. Implement Share or Connect if you have a website offering rich functionality.

- SHARE only requires one line of code and allows users to share your content with their friends.

- CONNECT enables users to log in and share their data with you with just one click, avoiding the hassle of filling out more forms and remembering another username and password. Once users are logged in you can customize their experience on your site by serving them specific content based on their interests, allowing them to make comments, and send specific content back to friends on Facebook.

Strategically, if you are more focused on content creation and publishing messages, links, photos or videos, then a Page is all you need. If you want to offer richer functionality, then do so on your website and implement either Share or Connect so visitors can share back with their friends on Facebook. Lastly, you could also use both: you publish links from your Page to drive fans to your website with Connect, where they can then share back content with their friends on Facebook.

Ben & Jerry’s is an example of a brand using both a Page and Connect:

Ben & Jerry's Page

Ben & Jerry's Connect Implementation

Ben & Jerry's Connect Implementation Screenshots

When your fans land on your Wall, you can show them content that you've posted or content from other fans - which should you choose?

The answer depends what you think your fans want to see and the type of content your fans are posting.

For Pages with a lot of fans and a lot of your own content, you probably want to show "Only Posts by Page" because you have great content that fans come for. Also, it's likely that most of your fans' wall posts are nice, but not that interesting to other fans. If you show both your content and other fans' content by default, your content will get drowned out by less interesting fan posts. Fans can always click "Just Fans" to see what other fans have posted.

Now if your fans are generating really interesting content that other fans may appreciate, then "Post by Page and Fans" may make more sense. An example is Petside.com's Page where fans are uploading lots of cute photos of their pets, and other fans are interacting with the content.

These are just general observations - please share your experience below!

Many Page admins want to build out their Page’s many tabs before publishing their Page. The reality is that the majority of your fans’ consumption and interaction with your content will happen with posts to your “Wall” because your Wall posts go directly to the fans’ homepage. Fewer fans will interact with what you put in your other tabs.

Here is an example from Starbucks where they ask fans to share their thoughts on a new product on their Discussions tab. They received over 16,000 pieces of feedback directly on the Wall post and just over 100 pieces of feedback in Starbucks’ Discussions tab. The explanation is simple – it is much easier for fans to interact with you from their homepage versus visiting your Page and having to go to a tab. Of course, you may get deeper and richer interactions on the tab, but you will likely get fewer.

To get started, don’t worry about building out your Page’s tabs, but rather just focus on posting interesting messages, links, photos, and videos to your Wall.
